measured_by: 3-item 7-point perceived safety scale (safe to ski; dangerous to ski; snowpack stability)
justification: “For judged safety, participants answered three questions…: 1) ‘Is it safe to ski the slope in these conditions?’ 2) ‘Is it dangerous to ski the slope in these conditions?’ (reverse-coded), and 3) ‘Is the snowpack stable enough to ski this slope?’ On a 7-point scale…”

measured_by: 3-item 7-point confidence scale (confidence in assessment; doubt judgment; confidence in snowpack safety)
justification: “For the degree of confidence in judged safety, participants answered three questions…: 1) ‘Are you confident in your assessment of the avalanche risk?’ 2) ‘Do you doubt your judgment of the avalanche danger?’ (reverse-coded), and 3) ‘Are you confident in your judgment of the safety of the snowpack?’ On a 7-point scale…”
“Participants…rated the scenario according to the following three adjectives: 1) ‘Attractive’, 2) ‘Uninteresting’ (reverse-coded), and 3) ‘Enjoyable’ on a 7-point scale…”

measured_by: 4-item 7-point experience composite (skiing ability; avalanche training; years of backcountry skiing; backcountry skiing days per season)
justification: “Participants then reported their skiing ability, avalanche training, years of backcountry skiing experience, and average number of backcountry skiing days per season, each of which was measured on a 7-point scale… We calculated a mean experience score per participant from the measurements of skiing ability, avalanche training, years of backcountry skiing experience, and average number of backcountry skiing days per season.”
